thread.title: TalkTalk: Hackers 'Can't Access Bank Accounts'

title: TalkTalk: Hackers 'Can't Access Bank Accounts'
text:
View Photo 

TalkTalk's chief executive has told Sky News that data stolen in this week's "significant and sustained" cyber attack is not enough for hackers to raid customers' bank accounts. 
Dido Harding could not confirm how many customers have been affected but, in an effort to reassure the company's four million customers, the TalkTalk boss said the latest information on the attack reveals it is much "smaller than originally thought". 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) said customers' names, addresses, dates of birth and some bank details may have been accessed, but full credit card numbers and passwords have not. 
"We don't store unencrypted credit card information on our website so any credit card information that has been stolen has the six middle digits of the credit card blanked out so can't be used for financial transactions," she said. 
The amount of information that may have been stolen - including bank account numbers and sort codes - is also significantly lower than initially thought, she revealed, adding that this is "extremely good news" for TalkTalk customers. 
Hackers will have access to "no more bank account information than is on a cheque", she said. 
She added that TalkTalk was working "tirelessly" to give its customers the "clarity they absolutely deserve", despite claims that TalkTalk has not done enough to keep its customers informed. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is also not yet known whether former TalkTalk customers have been affected. 
The Metropolitan Police is also investigating TalkTalk's claim on Friday that it may have been the target of a ransom demand by the hackers. 
Since the attack the company has been bombarded by complaints on social media sites from people who say they have fallen victim to scammers. 
TalkTalk customers remain exposed to so-called phishing phone calls, where scammers attempt to trick them into revealing the remaining information necessary to access their bank accounts. 
One customer, Kevin, told Sky News he was called by someone claiming to be from TalkTalk who knew his personal details. 
The person at the end of the phone was able to access his computer remotely while Kevin logged into online banking. 
He said he realised it was a scam when he overheard the caller telling a colleague how much he had in his account. 
Kevin said he was able to shut down his computer just as the person on the phone, who was controlling the mouse, began scrolling to the transfer button. 
This week's breach is the third in a series of cyber attacks that have affected TalkTalk customers. 
In August, the firm revealed its mobile sales site was hit by a "sophisticated and co-ordinated cyber attack" in which personal data was accessed. 
In February, customers were warned about scammers who managed to steal thousands of account numbers and names from TalkTalk's computers. 
In light of this latest attack, Sky News has compiled a list of basic precautions you can take if you're a TalkTalk customer. 
:: Action Fraud - the UK's national fraud and internet crime reporting centre - can be contacted on 0300 123 2050.
